This manual describes version &appversion; of &fr;.

sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: The &fr; is a graphical application for viewing, unpacking, and creating archive files. An archive file is a file that acts as a container for other files. An archive can contain many files, folders, and subfolders, usually in compressed form. There are many types of archives, using different formats and compression methods.
&fr; provides the following features:

listitem.para: Support for the following archive formats:
Uncompressed tar archive (.tar)
Tar archive compressed with gzip (.tar.gz, .tgz). This is the most common archive format on Unix and Linux systems.
Tar archive compressed with bzip (.tar.bz).
Tar archive compressed with bzip2 (.tar.bz2).
Tar archive compressed with compress (.tar.Z).
Archives created with PKZIP or WinZip (.zip). This is the de-facto standard archive type on Microsoft Windows systems.
Lha archive (.lha).
Rar archive (.rar).
Lha archive (.lzh).
Ear archive (.ear).
Jar archive (.jar).
War archive (.war).
Ability to view files in the archive using either Bonobo-enabled viewers for fast viewing or any application installed on your system when more advanced features are neeeded.
Ability to add or remove files from an existing archive.
Drag and drop support.

sect1.para: Please note that &fr; provides just the graphical interface; it relies on command-line utilities such as tar, gzip, bzip2 for for its operations. Thus, it will only support the formats listed above if you have appropriate command line tools installed on your system. Most Linux distributions include all of these tools.

To start &fr; open the Main Menu, then choose
Programs Utilities File Roller .
You can also start &fr; from the command line. To do so, type file-roller or file-roller filename.tar.gz and press Return. Here filename.tar.gz is the name of the archive file you want to open.

sect2.title: Opening an Archive File
sect2.para: To open an archive file, choose Archive Open (CtrlO), or click Open button in the toolbar. The Open Archive dialog is displayed. Select the file that you want to open, then click OK. &fr; will automatically determine archive type and and show its contents in the main window. You can also use Open button on the toolbar, or drag a file from another application such as a file manager.
If you try to open an archive file format that &fr; does not recognize, the application displays an error message.

If the archive file is very large, or you have a slow system, the operation of opening the archive can take significant time. If you want to abort this operation, press Esc key or click Stop button in the toolbar.

sect2.title: Viewing an Archive Contents
sect2.para: Once you have opened an archive, its contents is shown in &fr; main window (see ).

This window shows the list of all files and folders in the archive, with their names, types, modification dates and other information. Size field shows uncompressed size, i.e. the size the file would have if you extracted it from the archive. Date modified filed shows the date this file was last modified.

In addition, archive name is shown in window titlebar, and total number of files and size of the archive (uncompressed - i.e., the total size these fiels would have after extracting) is shown at the bottom of the window.

sect2.title: Folder View and File View
sect2.para: If the archive contains subfolders, you can choose one of two possible ways to show its contents, Folder View and File View. You can switch between these views using View menu.

In Folders View (default), the subfolders are shown in the same way as in a file manager. That is, for each subfolder the list shows the folder icon and the subfolder name. To view the contents of a subfolder, double-click on it. To go up one level in the folder tree, click on the Up button in the toolbar. In this view, the toolbar also contains Location field, which shows the full pathname of the currently shown folder.
In the File View, all files in the archive - including those in subfolders - are shown in a flat list.

sect2.title: Customizing the File List
sect2.para: &fr; allows you to customize the way files are shown as follows:

listitem.para: Switching between Folder View and File View - see .
Selecting the columns to show (Name, Type, Size, etc) - see .

Selecting the order of files in the list. You can have the files sorted by name, size, etc. To switch between these orderings, choose View Arrange Files. Alternatively, you can just click on the heading of the corresponding column; for example, to have files sorted by modification date (earliest to latest), click on Date modified heading. Clicking on the heading again reverses the order (in this case, it will order the files latest to earliest).

sect1.title: Viewing a File in an Archive
sect1.para: The simplest way to view a file in the archive is to double-click on the file in &fr; main window. Alternatively, you can select the file and click View button in the toolbar. &fr; will automatically determine the appropriate viewer or application for this file type (using information shown in File Types and Programs section of GNOME Control Center) and launch it. If &fr; can not determine the appropriate viewer or application, it will prompt you to select one.

note.title: Viewers and Applications
note.para: The difference between viewers and applications is that viewers show file contents inside a &fr; window and thus do not require launching a separate application. Viewers are usually much faster to start but have very limited functionality

For advanced users, we note that these viewers are not a part of &fr;. Instead, they are provided by other GNOME applications and use special technology (bonobo) which allows them to work inside &fr; window. Thus, the number of viewers available to &fr; depends on bonobo-enabled applications installed on your system.

warning.title: WARNING
warning.para: Please note that &fr; only allows you to view a file but not change it. If you open a file with an application and make any changes to it, these changes will not be saved in the archive, even if you clicked Save button in the application. (The reason is that &fr; creates a temporary copy of the file and then passes this copy to the application. This temporary copy is deleted after you close the application, and the changes are lost.)

If you want to edit a file in the archive and have your changes saved in the archive, you should extract the file to a temporary location, edit it, and then add this file back to the archive, overwriting the original.

sect1.para: You can also view a file using the viewer or application you specify rather than the default one. To open a file using an internal viewer, choose Archive View file or right-click on the filename and choose View file. &fr; will open the file using the most appropriate viewer for files of this type; if it can't find a viewer, it will try to show the file using text viewer.

To open a file using an external application, choose Archive Open Files... or right-click on the filename and choose Open Files .... This will open a dialog that shows all applications that can open files of this type. You can select one of them by clicking on it and then clicking OK. You can also manually enter the command to launch the application of your choice.

sect1.title: Modifying an Archive
sect1.para: &fr; allows you to modify an archive file. There are two types of operations: those that affect the archive as a whole (such as renaming the archive) and those that affect individual files or folders inside the archive.

Please note that all operations on the archive are saved to disk immediately. For example, if you are deleting a file from the archive, &fr; will delete it as soon as you click OK button. This is different from most applications which save the changes to disk only when you quit the application or select Save in the menu.

sect2.title: Operations on Archive as a Whole
sect2.para: The Archive menu of &fr; contains the following commands for modifying the archive file:

sect2.title: Adding Files to an Archive
sect2.para: The easiest way to add files to currently open archive is to drag files to &fr; window from another GNOME application (such as file manager). Alternatively, you can choose EditAdd Files..., click on the Add button in the toolbar, or right-click on a file in &fr; window and select Add files. This opens Add Files... dialog, shown in . In this dialog, select the files you want to add and click OK.

tip.title: TIP
tip.para: To select more than one file, hold down Ctrl key when selecting files. To select a continous block of files from the list, click on the first file, then hold down Shift key and click on the last file of the block. All files between them will be selected.

sect2.para: To add a whole folder to the archive, type the folder name in the Selection field. For example, say that you want to add the folder /aaa/bbb/ccc to an archive, in this case you have to go to folder /aaa/bbb and type ccc in the Selection field. Note that just clicking on the folder name does not work.
Add files dialog can also be used to automatically select and add all files satisfying certain criteria. This is discussed in .

Please note that when adding files to the archive, &fr; does not remove the original file; it remains unchanged. Also, the added file in the archive will have the same permissions and modification date as the original file.

sect2.title: Deleting Files From an Archive
sect2.para: To delete files from currently open archive, select the files you want to delete (see this tip on selecting multiple files) and choose EditDelete , or right-click on the selected files and choose Delete Files. This opens Delete Files dialog, which gives you a choice of deleting all files, selected files, or files matching a pattern. To learn more about filename patterns, see next section.

sect2.title: Adding Files - Advanced Options
sect2.para: As mentioned before, the simplest way to add files to an archive using Add Files dialog is just select the files you want to add (see this tip on selecting multiple files) and click OK. However, this dialog also allows you to automatically select and add files satisfying certain criteria. This section describes these features.

To automatically select all files matching a certain pattern, enter the pattern in Selection field. The pattern may use standard wildcard symbols * (matches any string) and ? (matches any single symbol). For example, pattern * matches all files, while *.tar* matches all files with extension tar, possibly followed by any sequence of symbols, for example filename.tar.gz. Please note that by default filenames in Unix are case-sensitive; you can override this by selecting Ignore case option, as described below.

You can also enter several patterns separated by semicolon (;). In this case, &fr; will select all files which match at least one of the patterns. For example, you can enter *.jpg; *.jpeg to select all files with extensions jpg and jpeg.
You can modify the selection using the following options in this dialog:

listitem.para: This option controls what happens if the archive already contains a file with the same name as the one you are adding. If this option is unselected, the file will be added, overwriting previous archive contents. If this option is selected, the file will be added only if it is newer than the file already in the archive (&fr; uses modification time to determine which file is newer).

tip.title: TIP
tip.para: This option is very convenient for keeping backups up-to-date. For example, assume that you have an archive backup.tar.gz which contain, in archived form, the contents of your home folder as it was a week ago. You want to update it so that it contains the contents of your home folder as it is now. To do so, open the archive in &fr;, click on Add button, select your home folder, select option Add only if newer and click OK. This will automatically add to the archive all files that have been created during the last week and update all files that have been modified during the last week. (However, it will not remove from the archive the files you have deleted during the last week.). This is much faster than doing full backup of your home folder.

listitem.para: If this option is selected, &fr; will select all files matching the pattern not only in the current folder but also in its subfolders. Please note that it is the filename that must match the pattern, not the subfolder name.

term.guilabel: Exclude folders that are symbolic links

listitem.para: If this option is selected, &fr; will not include files from folders that are symbolic links (i.e., pointers or shortcuts to other folders).

If this option is selected, &fr; will not include files from filesystems other than the current one. If you are not familiar with Unix notion of filesystem, this is roughly equivalent to including only the files that are physically on the same disk and partition as the current folder. In particular, this option will exclude files on removable media (CD's, floppies, Zip disks) and files on other computers in the network (such as files from an NFS filesystem), except for the one that contains the current folder.
If this option is selected, &fr; will not include files with the name ending with tilde (~). By a common convention, tilde is used for backup files.

If this option is selected, &fr; will not include files with the name starting with dot (.). By a common convention, these files are used for system information and applications' settings; they rarely contain user data.
This option allows you to exclude files whose name matches specified pattern. As with the Selection field, the pattern may use wildcards * and ?.

If this option is selected, &fr; will not distinguish between lower case and upper case symbols in the filename, so for example, pattern *.jpeg will match files with extensions jpeg, JPEG, or JpeG. If this option is not selected, &fr; will be case-sensitive, so *.jpeg will match files with extension jpeg but not JPEG.

sect1.title: Extracting Files From an Archive
sect1.para: To extract files from the archive, choose Edit Extract to... or click on Extract button in the toolbar. This will open Extract dialog shown in . This dialog is explained in detail in .

You can also extract only some of the files in the archive. To do so, select the files you want to extract in the main &fr; window before clicking on Extract button. For example, you can extract a single file from the archive.

Please note that extracting files from the archive does not change the archive file. &fr; leaves the archive file unchanged. If you no longer need the archive file, you can delete it manually by choosing Archive Delete .
Extracted files will have the same permissions and modification time as the original ones, no matter when you extracted them.

sect2.title: Extract Dialog
sect2.para: This dialog contains the following options:

listitem.para: This field shows the folder to which the files should be extracted. You can use Browse button to select a folder; you can also select one of recently used folders from the drop-down list or double-clcik on one of folders in Bookmarks list.

Please note that by default, &fr; reconstructs the folder structure when extracting. Thus, if you selected /home/sasha in Destination folder field, and your archive contains subfolder doc, then the contents of this subfolder will be extracted to /home/sasha/doc.

In this field, you can add folders which you frequently use for extraction. To extract to one of the folders in the favorites list, double-click on it. To add the folder currently shown in Destination folder field to the list of favorites, click Add to Bookmarks. To remove a folder from the list of favorites, select it with the mouse and click Remove button.

This option allows you to select files to extract. Possible options are All files (extracts all files in the archive), Selected files, and Files. The last option extracts files matching the pattern you enter. As usual, the pattern may use wildcards * and ?.

If this option is selected (default), then extraction will recreate the folder structure, creating subfolders as needed. If this option is not selected, all files in the archive (including those in subfolders) will be extracted to the target folder; no subfolders will be created.

varlistentry.term: Overwrite existing files and Do not extract older files

listitem.para: These two options control behavior of &fr; when the target folder already contains a file or subfolder with the same name as the one being extracted.
If Overwrite existing files is unselected, then existing files will not be overwritten, so &fr; will not extract files which are already present in target folder.

If Overwrite existing files is selected and Do not extract older files is unselected, then &fr; will extract all files from the archive, overwriting already existing files in the target folder if necessary. This is the default behavior.

If both Overwrite existing files and Do not extract older files are selected, then &fr; will overwrite existing files only if the file being extracted is newer than the existing file. &fr; uses last modification date to determine which file is newer.

With this option you can specify a password to use when extracting files. This option is disabled if the archive type does not support encryption, at the moment only ZIP archives support it. Please note that encryption provided by archive utilities are weak and insecure, if security is truly important for you use strong encryption tools such as the GNU Privacy Guard.
If this option is activated, after extraction of the files the destination folder is visualized with the Nautilus file manager. This is the only option of the extraction dialog which get saved.

sect1.title: Creating Archives
sect1.para: To create a new archive, choose Archive New or use New button in the toolbar. It will open the New Archive dialog, where you should enter the new archive name. By default, &fr; determines the archive type from the filename extension, so if you entered the filename archive.tar.bz2, &fr; will create a bzip2-compressed tar archive. You can also explicitly specify archive type using File type drop-down list, though it is not recommended.
After creating an archive, you can add files to it as described in .
Please note that &fr; will write the archive file to disk only after you add some files to it; it will not write to disk empty archives.

sect2.title: Preferences Dialog
sect2.para: To configure &fr;, choose Edit Preferences . This will open the Preferences dialog shown in .
Compression level regulates the speed of compression, if you choose a fast compression the resulting archive will be bigger than the one you could get choosing a slower compression level.
Recent archives allows you to specify how many recently accessed archives should be shown in &fr; Open Recents menu. By default, Recent archives is set to 5, so 5 most recent archives are shown.

Visible columns section allows you to select which columns should be shown in &fr; main window. Date modified shows the last time the file was modified. Path shows full path to the file (i.e., file name including all parent folders, such as /usr/share/doc/file-roller/Copying). Other columns should be self-explanatory.

sect2.title: Changing Keyboard Shortcuts
sect2.para: To change or add keyborad shortcuts associated with menu items, open the corresponding menu and move the mouse cursor over the menu item for which you want to change the shortcut (do not click on the menu item!). While the mouse cursor is over the desired item, press the key combination you want to use as the shortcut for this item. The menu will change to show the new shotrcut. That's it - now you can use the new shortcut.

tip.title: TIP
tip.para: You can use this method to change keyboard shortcuts in all GNOME applications.

tip.title: TIP
tip.para: In newer version of GNOME this feature is disabled by default, to enalbe it again you have to add the line gtk-can-change-accels = 1 to the file $(HOME)/.gtkrc-2.0.
